text: Pours hazy amber with average head that sticks around for while and leaves bit of lacing. Really well balanced. You can tell that water used to brew was of great quality and it shows. Has grassy taste with medium bitter finish. Medium bodied with great texture.

Sample from can as part of autumn big clean up. Aroma: raw wheat, caramel, light spices, light herbs. App: clear copper, small white head leaving great lacing. Taste and palate: light body, medium sweetness, caramel, strong medicinal notes, really strong astringent and bitter finish. Overall: ouch. That mouthfeel is really unpleasant. No idea if because its old but its sure really hard to drink. Will sure need to drink something else to get rid of this taste.

Appearance: slightly hazy pale amber, one fat finger of ivory head, good retention and moderate lacing. (3/5) Aroma: grainy malt, bready yeast, honey, grassy, light citrus. (5/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate bitter. (6/10) Medium body, moderate carbonation, off-dry medium duration bitter finish. (3/5)

Well, the up side to this one was its surprising bitterness, which though not high by comparison to many modern IPAs, might well be the highest Ive seen for any Molson product. The down side was well everything else. Grainy malt and bready yeast dominant the aromas, with weedy, grassy hops lurking in the background. Tastes slightly better than it smells, though, and its not terrible overall. Cant see bothering with another any time soon - or ever again. (11/20)
Bouteille de 341ml de blonde non filtrée avec belle mousse crémeuse. Au nez cest très parfumé floral et frais. En bouche cest assez intense avec une bonne amertume et le côté floral qui ressort.

A surprisingly flavourful and unique offering from Creemore. Great balance on the nose between honey and hops, with sweet honey predominating. A clean tasting beer, with the honey promised by the aroma being delivered in good balance with crisp hop bitterness. The hop profile is more prominent than many other beers of this type and is extremely welcome. Enigmatic hop notes, not easily attributed to one variety. Very drinkable.

Has a mild hoppy smell and taste to it. Not overpowering

Good amount of carbonation. Could have used a bit more.

Well worth a try, as is EVERY Creemore product.

MB
Can. Pours a true copper, fluffy white head, minor flecks of lace. Nose is straight up cereal. Tastes very grainy, a bitterness burn. Wouldnt say this is my favourite style of brew.

I love the Creemore product, even if it is a part of th Molson pile.
Always like the original Lager and I am an ale guy by nature, it is always in our fridge it is my wife"s go to beer.
The Keller is by far my fave, tasty good looking, unfiltered. This how beer is supposed to be.Please make more beers like this

Cloudy beer, thick grainy, grassy malt taste with a nice hop finish. Well balanced. Brewery with a good water source as the water base is nice. Maybe not a big surprise but the bottle version tastes better than the can version.

In can .. didnt enjoy this one. A little too bitter/hoppy and grainy. I found it not well balanced and poured it after about half the can.

I will not buy again
Tall Boy. Clear light amber pour with a good white head. Overall quite strong grain presence and some citrus. Fairly light, easy to drink body.
Malty aroma with caramel notes. Clear amber colour. Flavour of malt, lemon, and bread with short bitter finish. Medium body with lively carbonation. Quite pleasant.
Draft - Orange and some grainy notes. Copper with a white head. Lots of grains and some very light citrus. Refreshing and better than I expected.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2014 This is a better brew than I expected, given my previous experiences with Creemore (no hate, just no love). 
Looks great out of the bottle. Nose is faint, but pleasant: German malt with a bit of citrus and spice, as advertised. Taste is the same, with a nice, crisp, simple dry finish. Nothing about this beer pops, but its drinkable cottage fare.
On tap at the brewpub. A nice orange amber pour with a thick beige head. The taste is grainy caramel malts, some metallic tang, raisins, biscuit and a somewhat of a watery quality to it.
Poured from can. Some citrus hops aroma. Cloudy amber appearance with white head. Light bitter taste. Light body, oily texture, average carbonation. Overall a very nice and refreshing brew.

Can from lcbo. Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is warm bread dough. Medi body, medium carbonation. Lemon, orange, bread, toast.... Nice balance. Decent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dorée assez foncée et limpide, une mince mousse ne fait que passer sur le dessus du verre. Des arômes céréaliers et fruités, gracieuseté des houblons nobles utilisés, émanent du verre. En bouche, céréales, fruits et caramel se mélangent pour créer une bière tout de même goûteuse et bien faite.

Bouteille de 341 ml dégustée chez mon père. Arôme: Légère odeur de céréale. Apparence: La couleur est orangée légèrement voilée avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de céréale et dagrume. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dagrume en arrière goût. (Rating #5597)

473ml can. Looks light. Aroma of light malts and hints of wheat-like lightness, some floral hops, and dough with hints of spices. Flavor the same. Average to lighter texture. A decent beer for the style.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2015 2 week old 473 ml can from LCBO. Pours a hazy orange-amber with slightly off white head. Smells grainy, hoppy, peppery, bready, really nice. Taste is mostly is wonderfully hoppy, with a bright citrus earthy finish. Great lager
Poured a slightly hazy orange amber with a small off white head. Aroma of caramel malt and light fruit. Light body, flavour is medium sweet, medium bitter.
Hazy orange pour with big light orange head. Grass, floral hops. Taste is non-descript followed by spicy hop finish. OK at best. I will not be looking for it in future.

Poured a hazy orange colour with a nice one finger head. Lots of earthy German hops present. Quite well-balanced, with just enough bready malt for support. Not overly sweet. This is a bitter, earthy brew. A subtle fruitiness shows up as a nice extra bit of complexity. The finish isnt as drying as youd expect, given all the hops.

Rien dextraordinaire mais somme toute respectable. La première Creemore que javais bue lan passé était tellement insipide; au moins, celle-ci goûte quelque chose, quelque chose de bon de surcroît. Elle a du mordant au début et satténue rapidement...

Légèrement cuivrée et limpide, cette kellerbier (auto-proclamée) manque de corps lorsquelle sétend sur la langue. Le manque de houblons aussi est flagrant. Ça coûte cher du houblon, mais ça paye sur les papilles. Maintenant que le pot est lancé, voici les fleurs : cette bière est complète malgré ses manques. La base maltée offre des notes de caramel qui minent en rien le côté désaltérant du produit. Cest intéressant à plusieurs niveaux même si le grandiose nest pas de la partie.

473ml can. Hazy orange with a thin white head. Aroma is cereals, corn, caramel, fruits and grassy hops. Taste is grainy, sweet, citrusy, fruity and earthy with a bit of cardboard. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation, smooth texture.
Poured from 341mL bottle. Hazy, orange yellow with full white head. Musty yeast and citrus. Taste is grainy malt, dry hops and subtle citrus. Light-medium body.

Boisson orangée avec une fine mousse blanche, avec des effluves maltées et fruitées ; mince et moyennement pétillante. Bonne pointe damertume en bouche, mais ce sont les malts et les sucres résiduels, au demeurant parfaitement équilibrés, qui dominent en fin de compte. Un brin aqueuse, mais ses saveurs de caramel, ses houblons aromatiques et sa relative complexité (pour un style plutôt simple) la rachètent complètement. Une excellente keller.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2013 Pours a slightly hazy copper with a thin white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is of malt and grassy/floral hops. Taste is lightly sweet and lightly bitter, slightly fruity. Carbonation is high, body is medium-light and texture is slightly oily. OK

Dirty amber pour with a big white head. Pine, grass, caramel, dough, and toffee. Good amount of bitterness. A touch of sweetness, but mainly dry. A touch of fruity hops hanging on the back end. Great mouth on this. I like very much.

Olfactif: Arôme de Lager typique avec notes de grain et légèrement accompagné dépices telles la cannelle, l anis ainsi que de petits fruits et une touche de caramel. Lolfactif possède un haut potentiel aromatique mais sa puissance est faible et sestompe rapidement.
Visuel: Dorée / ambrée, très floue et avec des particules flottantes typiques de ce type de bière. Sa mousse est dépaisseur moyenne, rocailleuse, de bonne densité et persistant assez longtemps. La mousse colle bien mais la dentelle descend rapidement.
Gustatif: Lattaque développe une légère acidité avec des sucres efficaces et une finale légèrement houblonnée. Agrumes et épices sinstallent en douceur avec des notes de pamplemousse et de fruits tropicaux. Les sucres se développent en caramel principalement et lamertume en notes herbacées. On dirait une Allemande sur une base aromatique Belge. Les saveurs sont complexes et raffinées avec cependant un léger manque de puissance. En bouche, elle a beaucoup de corps et présente un bon équilibre.

Nouveauté au Québec. Bière dune couleur dorée, avec une mousse un peu fugace. Nez subtil de levure et dagrumes, avec un soupçon dépices. En bouche, cest surprenant et très goûteux. Belle acidité. Épices qui ressortent. Rien à voir avec une blanche de style belge où les notes sucrées et dagrumes prédominent. Ici, cest plutôt épicé et les houblons donnent une amertume intéressante. Jaime bien. Cheers!

473 ml can. Pours a hazy orangish light brown with a thin beige head. Aroma is spicy, malty and earthy. Flavour is malt, citrus, leather, dark spices and more earthiness. Finish is balanced and very slightly bitter.

341 ml bottle from local iga mix pack A: spicy and citrusy. app: hazy blond small white head. t/p: med body with quite long bitter finish. moderate carbonation. O: nice surprise. pleasing aroma with good mouthfeel. would be interested in having it available in sixer

On tap at St Augustines on The Drive in Vancouver. Maximum pour in their standard sleeve. No chimney, so no nose. A medium bronze color with a bit of beige head. Tastewise this is is a bit different; neither high-hop nor high-malt. I might have to pay attention on this one. Drinkable for sure. Both hops and malts present, but both are low key. Pleasant fruit and malt impressions.

Pours hazy gold with a fine cream head. Aroma of lemon, grass, slight grain, a little bit of yeast. Taste is reasonably malty up front, with a medium body and a firm spicy hop finish. Very German feel, definitely a great example of an unfiltered lager, the styles of which are certainly coming back into vogue across the pond.
First beer after helping Victoria move on a hot as shit day in June is crisp & refreshing & not a bad tall can to have ice cold. Otherwise wouldnt reach for it.

Pours a translucent gold with cream coloured head that lingers. Smells a touch sour with hints of hops and grass. 
Tastes of slightly bitter with a hint of spice, and pepper on the finish. 
Slightly carbonated. Not overly. A bit heavy but still crisp.
Not a bad beer for a change up : )

Pours a cloudy copper, with a foamy head, Aroma is of sweet malts, metallic, grains, and corn. Tasting notes include Corn, crackers, slight bitterns that lingers, astringent, slightly sweet. Dry finish to this beer, overall this is a great beer, and I would love to try it on tap.
Good example of a kellerbier.  Spicey notes in the aroma and a very crisp taste typical of creemore
Hazy golden orange pour with a thin white lace. Honey grain a aroma. Caramel malt flavour

Pours a cloudy copper colour with a quickly disappearing white head. Nice body and taste of grassy hops, grain and cereal with a subtle lemon citrus under liner. Easy drinker with great character and a good price.

Hazy orange color with a dense, low white head. Aroma is mild overall with a smooth grainy presence and some very low, slightly citrus lemon aroma. Flavor has a light grassy hops with some sweet lemon citrus and light cereal and grain presence. Body is pretty hefty for such a light brew. Overall a really tasty brew with a lot of character.

Unique cloudy, unfiltered look. Grainy malt with slight citrus aromas. Nice caramel malt with a tinge of citrus flavor, and a slightly bitter aftertaste. Really good balance of flavors, there is nothing to not like about this beer.

Final taste of my mix 6 pack. Pours a cloudy Orange-Copper color with a quickly disappearing medium white head. Malt aroma with a hint of citrus. Citrus, Zest taste with some definite hops near the end but its all well balanced. Very good! Creemore was a pleasant surprise.
Nice beer. Im not really familiar with the style but this brew is spicy, bitter enough, hoppy without being hoppy for the sake of being hoppy and very well balanced.

Light copper pour. Subdued aroma, but what I can get is light grain, citrus, and a touch of other fruit. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Flavour is medium roasted malt with very slight hints of citrus and pine. Finishes crisp with a subtle hop bite.

Clouded deep orange, small lasting off white head. Spicy, zesty, malty aroma. Malty herbal hop taste, some citrus. Softly carbed, medium bodied, moderately hopped. Bitter hop finish. Good lager. LF (Lagerboy Friendly)

471 ml can shared with czar and friends. Pours a rather opaque orange with a short lasting white head. Smell is fruity, cereals. Taste is cereals, sweet, malty, fruity, oranges. Nice, well-balanced herbal bitter finish. Medium to light body. Very good starter.

Can from the LCBO. Unfiltered/cloudy vibrant amber with a nice slightly off white head that remains throughout. A little metallic at first but that does fade if you let the beer air out; grainy, muted citrus with some lemon zest, bit earthy. Moderate body, mild carbonation, very slight bitterness, a surprisingly long earthy and hoppy finish. Quite nice.

[can]
Fruity aroma masked by a prominent sulfur problem that holds back some apricot and base malt. Almost clear orange-amber under a lasting, off-white cover. Fruity apricot flavour with some white grape and a touch of cardboard. Decent bitterness, if a bit weak. Transcendent sulfury off-flavour. Medium body, medium carbonation, moderately bitter finish.

(500mL can from LCBO) Poured cool, a very hazy brownish orange with a moderate white head that disappeared instantly. Aroma grainy malts, some light citrus and a bit of grassy herbs and spices.  Flavour is cereal malt and some caramel, spice from the yeast and grassy hops, moderately sweet with a little bitterness towards the finish. Quite light-bodied, fairly soft carbonation. An OK kellerbier but nothing on the best examples from Germany, with relatively light yeast and hops character and a weak finish.

Can @ Home.
Pours orange cloudy, with off white full head. Unfiltered indeed!
Taste is very full, but fresh, with citrus, spices and a nice bittery aftertaste. Still it is a smooth drink, which lingers on your palate. Well balanced, nothing standing too much. Just as a good Keller should be. 
Ideal for the summer, more interesting than your average weißen (not Schneider of course).
Nice one!

Aug 28, 2012. 473ml can pours hazy orange with small fleeting off white head and no lacing. Aroma is typical creemore springs - sourdough bread with touches of spice and citrus on the nose. Caramel sweetness from the malt and hint of orange peel in the flavour. Little bitterness in aftertaste but mostly just mild caramel malt with some spice and a medium body. Nothing much left on tongue. Better than most other offerings from brewery (not saying much) but not even close to the urbock it replaced.

341ml bottle. Smell is mild but citrus and pepper. Opaque orange in the glass (Lovibond 13/14) with no head. Spotty lace. Interesting and unique flavoring. Starts with a short hops burst but rolls into a caramel finish with tones of sugar maple as well. Honey and Pepper In the aftertaste.  Palate is fairly clean with moderate carbonation level.
Opaque amber,lasting beige head.Beery malt nose.Light malt profile,fruity hints,med strength lasting hop finish

Golden orange in colour with a thin but lasting white head, good lacing.  The aroma is herbal, some grains and cereal, grass with a bit of caramel malt  sweetness.  The flavour is of cereal and grains, mild caramel sweetness, grassy.
Lightly bitter mouthfeel, light body, mild carbonation.  Finishes average length, sweet.

More of the same from Creemore lately really, their Lager has gone downhill, the Urbock isnt what it used to be and this is just okay.

473ml can purchased at the LCBO in Peterborough, Ontario.
No date.
Opened on May 24, 2010.

Tall can. Pours almost orange and cloudy. Lots of foamy white head. Flavourful and smooth with notes of orange, tasty malts and some spice. Light to medium-bodied, low carbonation, slightly creamy mouthfeel, soft bitter finish. But the odour threw me. Smells like used sweatsocks. I couldnt get past that and had to drop the rating quite a bit. Otherwise, its another solid Creemore brew.
Crisp aroma. Beautiful cloudy orange. Thin white head. Extremely smooth and despite the mild taste the aftertaste is really long.

Can. Hazy orangey-amber with a head that starts thick and then goes down to mountains sticking out of a lake, which is a classic kellerbier head formation.  Gently fruity hop character.  Fruity hops, subtle pale bready malts.  Decent balance.  As non-Franconian kellerbier goes, this is one of the better ones.

Single can purchased from an LCBO in Ottawa, Ontario on 06/06/2012. Colour: Medium organge with brown hues and low white head. Nose: Delicious ripe prarie grains splashed with an orange peel rain shower. A light boiled egg essence. Swirling produces faint traces of pine tree. Taste: Medium-light sweet, medium-light bitter, medium-light sour. The orange peel comes surging forward. A meaty taste comes mid-palate...almost like plain chicken wing. Roasted grains with a splash of hop bittnerness finish things off. Drinkable but slightly unbalanced.

Can at the Manx. Foams up nicely, good head, hazy amber. Aroma had a surprising amount of authenticity. Dry hops, just the right amount of yeast, a few mushrooms. Very soft palate allows mushrooms to linger a while. Lively yeast and solid pale malt body. Surprisingly authentic and decent!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hazy orange colour with half a finger of creamy white head. Bready with touches of spice and citrus on the nose. Sweetness from the malt and some orange peel in the flavour. Little bitterness and a medium body

Foggy copper body with little visible carbonation, small head on top. Soft woody aroma with a finish of hops, slight caramel hints. Flavour is a good mix of citrus and hops with a dry finish; some malt notes on the back end. Really nice in fact, and way better than anything else Ive had from this brewer.

My first Kellerbier experience, from a bottle pours a nice hazy orange with a pretty nice head.  Some nice citrus on the nose with a bit of herb and flower.  Pretty clean on the palate with some bitterness, finishes pretty quick.  Surprisingly tasty.

On tap @ stacked Smokehouse Toronto. Pours a slightly hazy amber with a nice rich head. Notes of citrus.  Nice soft caramel and malt offset with a hop profile similar to Creemore Lager. Enjoyed this almost as much as the lager.

473 mL can. Pours amber, with a frothy off white head, nice lacing, not as cloudy as some unfiltered beers. Subtle spices and a little caramel aroma, grass and cereal with a bit of hops and some cedar notes.  Great easy drinking lager, clean, bitter with a lingering sourness that is quite pleasant. Light bodied, medium carbonation, relatively abrupt finish. Another very sessionable Creemore product.

Dark orange cloudy body with big yellowish head, decent retention, nice lacing.
Grassy hops is the main course in the aroma today, spring water freshness, herbal-floral hints, orange peel. 
Awesome taste: bready, hoppy, herbal, good dose of bitterness, soft finish. Very harmonious combination.

This was the first kellerbier Id ever had. Smells caramelicious and tastes like roasted dust, in a good way (yes there is a good way). Smacks your cheeks guts. Kudos to Creemore for taking the road less travelled.

Lata, gracias al señor Plovmand. Hazy ambewr colour, medium white head, ok lacing. Pleasant sweet hoppy malty fruiti bit yeasty like aroma. Good mouthfeel. Flavour has caramel and malt with fruit and yeast, some citrus. Quite pleasant.
Nice session beer. Well balanced between the noble hops and the malty profil of this brew.

Smells hoppy, a bit floral like a good American Pale Ale. Head pours gassy and has a little retaining power, lots of carbonation. Amber colour. Citrus peel astringent taste with some sourness. Not bad - better than creemore springs lager and certainly better than the misguided urbock. Its alright, but nothing Im going to rush back to. Its different from the average beer, if anything. Tall can
2 finger head buybble amber or something. Smells kinda lemony limey ish sort of and taste that way ab bit with btterness and sites really heavy. Noit the worst thing I had but I dont like it.
Can.... It pours hazy deep golden with a small off white head..... The aroma is caramel, hops and fruit... The flavor is hops, citrus and caramel....bitter finish....

Can provided by TheJester. Thanks! Pours hazy deep golden with a medium off white head. The aroma is caramel, earthy hops, fruit and a pleasant bitterness. The flavour is citrus, caramel and is quite fresh overall. Bitter pleasant finish.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2016 Hazy copper pour, 2 fingers of head.  Subtle aroma - Grassy, hoppy, some caramel.  Fairly light tasting for a Keller - Grassy, sweet, caramel malt.  Fairly smooth.  I liked it but compared to other Kellers Ive had this one comes off as lightweight.
Pours a nice orange with a head that last a bit. Really nice depth to this one. Very grassy hop presence up front. Strong carbonation, really nice beer.

473ml can pours a golden orangeish color with a big white head that settles quickly and leaves only a few spots of lacing.  Aroma is light  grain and earthy hops.  Taste is light malty sweetness with an earthy hop bitterness in the finish.  A decent enough beer, but nothing special.

Pours out a bright orange amber with some haze in the body and a finger of light beige head. The nose is sweet with a definate German yeast note and nice light fruit. A sweet German malt with a nice hop character on the nose. The taste is unexpectantly bitter in comparison to the nose. A sweet caramel malt and light yeast note with some light grassy and biscuit. There is a full body with a slick and chewy mouthfeel. overall, a surprising and delicious Kellerbier from Creemore.
From can.  Pours with slight foamy white head and a hazy amber colour true to the style.  Not much of an aroma, but tastes clean with a slight bitter hit.

from can, pours a cloudy dark orange colour with a clearly carbon dioxide induced head that fizzes away before promptly dissapating to nothing. bready malts on the nose. flavour is a let down, theres just nothing going on. Once the fizz leaves your tongue your left with some malty flavours but it just feels watery and thin. hmmm.... nothing to see here, keep walking...

My Bottom Line :  
Burnt caramel notes and green leafy hops harbor fruity edges in this prickly and quenching Kellerbier. 

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-Fluffy sheets of foam disappear into the misty golden amber. 
-Prickly bubbles and slender residual sugars make for good drinkable.
-Hop character is authentic throughout; leafy, citrusy and spicy too, especially upon warming.
-Toasted cereal flavors are engaging. The burnt sugars though (direct fire) can get a tad too present for my liking.
-While Im not a fan of the grain bill in this one, I have to say this is the closest any Canadian brewery has gotten to a real Franconian Kellerbier. Bravo! Their Pilsner is even more compelling imho.
-Mineral notes peek through here and there. Water? Can?

Can.

473ml can originally from the LCBO, acquired in a trade. Not much aroma, a little hops. Poured a cloudy yellow/orange, unfiltered. Taste was very pleasant, good malt, hoppy for a lager without being too bitter. Body was medium, carbonation was good without being fizzy, really smooth and refreshing. Overall, a really good lager, Id like to try more in this style.
Can from LCBO.  Pours dark orange and cloudy.  Citrus floral aroma.  Huge hoppy flavour, without much bitterness.  Very nice.
On tap in Toronto. Brown colour. Malty sweet flavour and aroma. A decent beer.
Excellent kellerbier. Can 473 ml. Pours a dark orange (almost red) colours with moderate white head. Citrus flavours with bready malts. Lots of hops.  Nice finish.
Pours a nice cloudy bronze colour with a thin head which dissipates quickly. Aroma is a floral citrus. taste is crisp light  citrus and malts back and a light spice hoppiness very enjoyable
Got a variety pack at lcbo and a 473 can, poured a hazy golden color with a foamy white head.  Good carbonation.   Floral, citrus notes to it, smooth texture, good hoppy bitter finish.

Canette 473ml. De couleur orange-ambrée et légèrement voilée. Nez de houblon herbeux (herbes fraîches) aux notes florales et citriques, de biscuits, léger de pain et de grains de malt caramélisés et aux faibles notes rôties, léger de fruits (agrumes) et avec des notes de noix. Moyenne-mince en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture légèrement crémeuse. Léger goût fruité (agrumes) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de grains de malt légèrement caramélisés et aux petites notes rôties, un moyen goût de biscuit et des notes de pain. Parallèlement, lon retrouve une moyenne-légère amertume asséchante de houblon herbeux (herbes très fraîches) aux notes florales et aux traces citriques jusquen finale, où lon y retrouve également des notes de noix et des traces dépices (poivre doux). Post-goût moyen-long et plutôt sec, moyennement amer de houblon herbeux aux notes florales avec un léger goût fruité (zest dagrumes) ainsi que des petites notes rôties et de noix.

July 25, 2011; 5.0% abv; 473mL tall can, refrigerated, BBD: None, pint glass

Aromas of grass, caramel malt with a light floral touch. Pours a golden strawerry red with a 3/4 inch head. Yeasty cloudiness with light bubbles; barely visible. Tastes of caramel malts, citrus and grassiness. Herbal and light bitterness from the hops with a slight yeasty mustiness... sort of like a cellar. Not much of an aftertaste, surprisingly quick. A fairly thick mouthfeel with very little sharpness. Finish is abrupt and lends to fast drinking. Quite aleish. Not bad. New to the style and I probably need a few more tastes. Interesting.

473mL can from the LCBO.  Pours orange with a large, fluffy head.  Aroma is spicy hops.  Flavour is hoppy up front, very nice, creamy mouthfeel, with plenty of bready malts on the back end.  Not as malty as I remember it being last year, but still a very good beer.

473ml can. Pours orange with haze. Decent looking white head on top, very bubbly with good lacing. Great fresh nose featuring fresh cut grass/hay and a bit of citrus. Flavour has nice bready malts and a citrusy hop flavour, (juicy, orange peels notes). Good bitter finish, grassy aftertaste with some haylike notes, dry. Soft body, mild natural feeling to the carbonation, feels smooth in the mouth. Very nice kellerbier.

473 ml can purchased at the Rideau and King Edward LCBO (Ottawa), on July 10, 2011. Gold dark, small head. Leaf aroma hops, some citrus sec. Taste hop flavored with lemon and herbs, not very bitter but sweet enough. That was nice!
can, nice pour, good head. some roasty caramel malt flavour but not much else. not a huge creemore fan but this wasnt bad

draught. pours slightly hazy (though by no means opaque) copper. Nice colour. Aroma is hoppy. Taste is biscuity malts, sharp hops, maybe a little citrus in there too. Like others have said, nothing groundbreaking in this beer, but what it does it does very well.

Pour orange white head minimal lace. Aroma caramel, malt, grass, grain, cereal, corn. Taste cereal, grain, grassy, decently bitter. MF medium body fizzy carb. Overall meh nothing special and has some off tastes I cant really place.

Originally rated August 2009. Nice... a new Creemore Springs brew ! Glad to see a new product, even if Molson bought them out. Pours a golden-orange caramel colour with a good frothy head that stays a while and leaves good patchy lace. Carbonation is pretty tame with tiny little bubbles. Says "generously hopped" on the can, and you can smell the beautiful floral hops. Also, kind of grainy and hazy a bit (as it also says on the can "Unfiltered") but wish it would be even less filtered. Again, the nice blend of hop and grain malts in the taste. Very well blended, but not trying to piss-off the mass market drinkers. Quite a refreshing beer with more taste than swills, for summer. Nice to see a brewer do a Killerbier when everyone else is doing witbier (as a trend) this summer.

Not the freshest can drank, Ive definitely had better, very fresh is best. Cloudy orange colour. Orange peel, and pepper and clove spice smell. Tastes of sweet biscuity malt, softer carbonation and deliciously soft hopped bitterness, grass in the finish. Med-thin body. Pretty good.

473ml can, amber-orange color, with a beige head, yeasty, fruity nose of faint tropical fruits, pears and grapefruit rinds, from the nice floral hop used, with some mild toasted, biscuity malt, toffeeish aromas follow through on a medium-bodied palate with a crisp yeasty, fruity,citrusy, spicy character with a mild flowery hop leafy, lemon zesty flavor, with some faint toasty, biscuity, caramel malt undertones, leading towards a light toasted malt, lingering citrus, leafy hop bitterness finish.

Can, sent to me from Kingston Ontario. Pours a bright new-penny copper orange, hazy, with a robust golden head that thickly laces the glass. Aroma is surprisingly hoppy, with grassy and spicy nuances predominating. Light caramel malts take a backseat to orange pith and tea leaf hoppiness, with spic nuances. Nicely bitter finish. This would be a permanent member of my beer fridge if I could get it out here. An awesome session beer.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 473 mL can from the LCBO, served in a lager glass. Pours hazy golden orange with a tall, rocky off-white head. The head fades to a thin cover, leaving behind a small amount of loose lace. The nose has big citrus and hop aromas along with pale malt, spice, flowers and yeast. The flavour is moderately bitter throughout, with notes of leafy hops and spice. It is mildly sweet up front, but becomes less so by the finish. The finish is long, dry and hoppy with a slight acidic feel. On the palate, it is medium in body with a dry texture and lively carbonation. On the whole, this is a flavourful, hoppy lager with a good dose of dry hopping. While the hops are nice, they overpower the malts and throw the balance off. The elements are all nice, but together somehow less. 2010-10-14

Hops are evident from the first sniff.  Quality hops at that.  Generous amounts of lace on the glass, cloudy amber body with bubbly head.  Flavor is by no means distinct, just hits the pleasure centers of your tongue simultaneously as you swish the rich, velvety liquid around in your mouth.  Before you know it, the slowly increasing arpeggio of joy erupts into a maelstrom of orgasmic proportions.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2013 pours cloudy, almost murky orange, large head, excellent retention and lacing. orange zest, crisp, lightly toasted and spicy malts. average carbonation, light ot medium body, very nice herbal-citrusy finish. sessionnable. quenching. really nice!
Same can as pictured. Weak aroma and flavour. Can was slightly old. Probably wouldnt purchase again.

Pours a ever-so-slightly-murky orangey-brown with respectable head that hangs around.  Im once again reminded how grateful I am that molson didnt mess these folks up.  Wild range of flavours in this one.  From a floral and very piney hoppiness to open moving into a mildly sweet caramel maltiness, to lingering bitter grassy hops.  Bright, lively flavours in excellent balance.

Can. Murky Creemore with refreshing, crisp hops.. ok.. thats simple..and unfair.. but kinda.. floral and citrusy..light malt with a full and rich body.. ok.. its not the regular creemore.. this is a distinct and unique offering.. more then i would have expected post molson. Would definately buy again. Very drinkable, good respecatble brew.

Draught.  Pours golden amber colour with average off-white head.  Aromas of hops, citrus (orange) and yeast.  Taste is creamy and slightly bitter with subtle notes of orange and yeast and some spice.  Not a bad beer, but not my favourite Creemore though.
The initial taste of this beer was not very enjoyable. However as I drank it more it became very nice, it has a nice smoothness and a nice bitter finish. I would try this again

dark gold pour with a thick foamy white head.
aroma is light caramel malt. some fruity floral hop tones, and a slight vegetable hint.
Flavour is light to medium sweet toasted maltiness. hints of citrus to the fruitiness. more of that light floral hop in the finish.

Can from the LCBO. Pours amber, reallly hazy. Impressive pale beige head, somewhat foamy, resorbs fast, lace remains. Yeast-heavy on aroma : otherwise, some fruits (apricots), floral hops. Taste is a wee bit metallic (can?), somewhat bitter before the final, some spruce taste as well. Finale is smooth, but rather long. Very interesting brew that Id really like to try on tap.

thx to sammy for the trade
head: 1/2 inch , light beige 
colour: warm orange cloudy amber 
smell: yeast , hops, some flaw peachyness, sweet malts
taste: bitter malty start, then comes a stingy hopy flavour , some bitteness of citricpeel too , some yeast , and quite some body for a 5%abv beer 
end is dry and has a milky flavour , aftertaste is a bit grassy and carbonation is low 
more pleasant than any lager i ever drunk before ... really nice

Can from LCBO. Slightly cloudy golden orange with a medium off white head with good retention.  Aroma is a bit skunky with herbal and floral hops, sweet malt and metal. Flavor is herbal and floral hops, biscuity malt, sugar and earthy notes and a bitter finish. Thin to medium body with medium carbonation.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2013 Cannette 473 ml. 5%. Couleur ambrée mousse blanche-beige. Arome de levure, de malt et un peu fruitée. En bouche elle est légèrement crémeuse, amère et maltée. Finale avec une amertume houblonneuse.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2011 Amber-gold pour with very satisfying head retention and some lace. Well-rounded, hoppy mouthfeel with an underlying bready taste makes this a very enjoyable beer for a hot summer night. Possibly my favorite from Creemore and Im glad to see them bringing out interesting styles.

Re-rate one year later:

got a bunch of this on tap. Its cloudy as hell. I love it. This is some fresh beer for sure. Lace and head are sticky and thick. Hop presence is alive and fruity with definite bubblegum and gummy bear auras. Hops are a key factor here. All-around this beer is fantastic. Dark honey/amber colour and bombastic taste make this a stellar release by Creemore. Hats off for sure.

Can from LCBO in Toronto. Golden pour with a white film of head. Biscuity malt nose with some peppery noble hop character. Light body with a crisp dry flavour- biscuity and softly sweet malt character with a balancing noble hop presence. A very nice and German feeling lager.
A surprisingly satisfying summer beer. Pours clear light amber with large frothy white head. Powerful floral aroma. Goes down easy, light refreshing and enjoyable.

Can LCBO. Delicious. Pours golden, cloudy, with thick white head. Hoppy, somewhat sweet aroma. Lovely mouth feel, medium bodied with appropriate carbonation. Sweetness in the taste with slightly bitter finish. A beautiful beer.
Aroma is dusty lager with a hint of pine. Cloudy golden orange with white foamy head that laces as it thins. Sweet, smooth, with some bitterness.

Can. Vivid cloudy amber body and a thick, long-lasting head. Tantalizing aromas of spice (nutmeg & cinnamon), lemon and malt. Trademark malty Creemore flavour profile, nice carbonation and a pleasant woody finish. Very likeable.

500ml can from LCBO
Appearance :Clear pale amber small fluffy head.

Aroma : Herbal hops, biscuits malt. Bready. Slightly spicy and leafy hops.

Taste : A bit sweet. Notes of honey or light caramel. Slightly bitter, herbal hops. Malty. Notes of biscuits and bread. Finish is rather dry with s slight bitterness. Notes of fruits. Finish is very slightly warm.

Overall : Great taste. Nice light sweetness. Really drinkable and refreshing. Nice hops. Great dry finish.

473mL Can from the LCBO. Cloudy, brownorange pour with a creamy tan head that dissipates slowly. Aroma is medium hops, orange zest and mild spiciness. Mouthfeel is creamy, low-medium carbonation. Taste is delicately hopped, with mild sweet malts and a slight spiciness. Delicious.

This is my final unrated style of beer on Ratebeer.  I got this un from Canada in a great big box from Matt7215.  Thanks a bunch for killing this want.  Hazy copper pour with a monstrously thick head.  Nose is caramel and sugary sweet.  Lotsa malt.  Sweet spiciness.  Taste is not nearly as sweet as the nose.  Cantalope bitterness followed by more bitterness, and then aspirin bitterness.  Tiny high sweetness hiding in the aspirin and hay.

Orangy cloudy brown with ample off white head. Aroma is hop malt, with a tiny tiny bit o must. Very mild citrus like a light spice. Body is ample with decent carbonation. Very nice on the palate and not too complicated.

Malty and hoppy scent.  Very fresh smelling.  Orangish pour with a firm thick head.  Very easy drinking.  Goes down very smooth.  Not much flavour at first, the majority is in the aftertaste.  Caramel and malts and something just slightly bitter in the finish.  Rather good.  Surprisingly good for Creemore.
Canette de 473ml. Bière dorée-orangée, pas filtrée. Houblonnée à souhait, très agréable en bouche, mordante avec beaucoup de caractère.

20oz draught 
5.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on May 28, 2010 at "The Beerbistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer apopeared a hazy golden orange colour with a thich white head that lasted a while.  The aroma was grainy malt, with some floral hops in the mix.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied with medium carbonation.  The flavour was primarily grainy malt, with some citrusy sweetness in the finish.
473 ml can from LCBO.  Pours copper in colour, decent off white head.  Aroma and taste of a beefy lager.  Didnt notice any cloudyness.  Pretty good.

473ml can. Pours a golden amber with off white head, gradually diminishing as the experience continues. Tangy citrus and floral aromas on the nose with a touch of malty sweetness. Citrus and grassy flavours on the palate with a caramel malt flavour as well. Light medium mouthfeel with the finish leaving a lingering bitterness with a medium-dry touch. Very nice and flavorsome lager.

pours a hazy amber-gold with a small but appropriate and staying head. smell is sulfur, nothing else detectable. taste is quite sweet, light caramel malt, little alcohol burn. brutish, very spicy hop taste, probably not noble. palate is average verging on the ouch bubbly feeling of typical north american beer. this was so bloody hard to get, what a huge let down aside from its very nice apperance. after this and their "pils" im not bothering with BMC owned creemore anymore

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2013 Une multitude de canettes du LCBO et maintenant quelques bouteilles achetées au supermarché du coin.  Une belle robe couleur orangé avec la présence dune mousse pleine de ténacité qui laisse beaucoup de traces derrière son passage.  Au nez, beaucoup de citron frais et un surprenant parfum dananas qui apparaît au fil des gorgées.  Au goût, un liquide crémeux qui révèle un bel équilibre entre le malt (caramel et pain) et les fleurs de houblons.  Une finale sèche, citronnée et florale.  Superbe.

473ml can.  Pours a cloudy orange / tan with a thin white head.  Faint aromas of pine, citrus, tropical fruit, alcohol.  Slightly sweet, with heavy malt, peach, citrus, and bitter hops in the finish.  Was expecting something far more exciting.  Good, not great.

473 ml can from LCBO.  Pours a cloudy light copper with moderate-sized white head with decent retention.  Aroma is bready, citrus with definite floral hops and a bit of yeast.  Taste is bready and floral/grassy with lemon noticeable too.  Fairly dry finish.  Very good.

Very refreshing. Strong mango aroma (remarkable, really!). Flavour is peach, mango, and citrus... exotic and impressive. Hops are strong, bitter and obvious. Carbonation is very noticeable. A bit of a sweet corn flavour underlines the whole thing - I usually dislike that, but the fruitiness and uniqueness of this beer make it its own. Interesting and worth trying for sure.
Really crisp lager with lots of hops and some spice. Extra refreshing, smooth, and very drinkable. Not huge flavour but its real good for what it is.

Poured from can. Orange copper colour. Hazy that poured wonderful with decent head. Very inviting!! Hops aroma with some citrus. Very unique. Full flavor with lots of hops and can still taste a bit of the citrus. Refreshing and great for summer!!

Orangey with a bit of haze. Smells like springtime! Hint of citrus, touch of herbs. Light aroma overall. Absolutely delicious as well. More robust than a lager, yet more refreshing than most ales. Goes down really smooth, but leaves a lingering taste that fades beautifully.

Really great stuff, perfect for summer.

473ml can from LCBO (Dundas/Mavis)

This is a nice beer by Creemore.  Unlike most people, I dont get a whole lot of citrus from it but predominantly HOPS HOPS and more HOPS.  Appearance is a very pretty clouded amber color, pours with a thick foamy head that lasts for a little while.  Some moderate lacing in the glass.  Would definitely buy this again, missed it last season and am glad to have snagged a few cans this time around.

Can, 473 ml, gift from Luc Bourbonnière (merci!), savoured on September 10 2009; eye: orangey, hazy, suspended matter, tiny ring of beige head, light lacing; nose: orange, citrus, hops, slight malt, Lemon Pledge; mouth: orange, citrus, slight hops, malt is more present than the nose suggests, finale in malt with light presence of hops; overall: nice surprise

FRANÇAIS

Canette, 473 ml, cadeau de Luc Bourbonnière (merci!), savourée le 10 septembre 2009; il : orangée, trouble, matière en suspension, petit anneau de mousse beige, légère dentelle; nez : orange, citron, houblon, très léger malt, « Lemon Pledge »; bouche : orange, citron, très léger houblon, malt plus présent que le nez le suggère, finale en malt avec légère présence de houblon; en résumé : belle surprise

Draught at Victory Cafe and cans from the brewery. It has a rich copper hue with a hazy body, and a remarkably fresh and enticing aroma that holds notes of toasted grain, dried grass and juicy hops, along with a hint of yeast. The body is lightly carbonated, and while the flavour seems a bit muted at first, giving the beer a few minutes to warm allows it to open up considerably, revealing a perfect balance between sweet, caramelish malt and pleasantly bitter hops, with a delicate suggestion of lemon zest in the finish. The yeast is also noticeable, but not overpowering, it just adds a well integrated depth and richness to the flavour. An excellent beer all around, and one that I hope Creemore Springs brings back, as I couldnt get enough it if for the few weeks it was available this past summer.

Can [473ml]. Pours a slightly hazy golden-amber with an average size lasting foamy white head. Nice aroma of biscuity malt, citrus fruit, floral hops, some sweetness and yeast. Great refreshing flavour of biscuity malt, a surprising amount of floral hops (in a good way!), fruit (citrus and peach), a hint of spices and a nice, dry bitter finish. Medium bodied, almost creamy mouthfeel. Not only is this the best Creemore beer, its one of the best beers made in Ontario -- Please Creemore, make this again!

16 oz can.  Pours a clear dark gold body with a one finger frothy white head that left some patchy lacing.  Lightly toasty and bready malt with just a light floral hoppiness, maybe a touch of yeast.  Pretty simple and straightforward, but theres a bit of softness on the finish that may be from the yeast.  A little toasty with crusty bready malt, very light bitterness on the finish.  Lighter bodied with a nice almost creamy softness and light carbonation.  Not bad, but certainly no reason to seek it out other than for the style.  Toward the bottom of the style for me.

Can: Poured a bright lightly hazy copper color lager with a large foamy head with average retention and some lacing. Aroma of dry caramel malt with floral undertones and some clean crisp hops. Taste is a well balanced mix between some floral malt with notes dry caramel and a light green hoppy finish. Body was quite full with good carbonation. Very well done though additional hops would have benefited this beer as well as slightly less filtration.

A golden orange beer with a thon lacing white head. In aroma, an intense mix of German hops, herbal and pungeant, orange pulp, pledge lemon, fruity esters, quite nice.  In mouth, a good sweety nutty malt, grainy mash, and good German hops, a bit light in mouth. Can from LCBO, shared with probstk, Sept. 12 2009.

Can from the LCBO.  Clear body, fluffy white head.  Nose is spicy noble hops, reallly nice toasted malt, a small amount of caramel, some fruitiness.  Flavor is that nice toasted malt, decent hop (Id like a bit more) flavor.  Finish has really great maltiness, maybe a small hint of sulfur & more of that noble hop goodness.

One of my favourite beers in recent memory.  Why?  Cause its was so pleasantly balanced.  It had nice spicy hops but not too much to make it just a sipping beer.  It was light enough to be able to enjoy more than one at a time.

If anyone has had the Tankhouse by Miss St. then Id say its like a lighter less bitter version (and thats not knocking the Tankhouse).

Canned sample via sammy. Pale orange in colour with a bit of haze and medium carbonation. Aromas of mild citrus, herbal hops, pale malts, and yeast. Great herbal hop flavors dominate the palate, supported by tea buscuit like malts, sublte yeast notes, and a hint of tart orchard fruit. Fairly dry and very refreshing on the finish. Well balanced. I could drink lots of this.

16 oz. can - thanks Sammy for the trade; dark gold with slight haze and thin white head; mix of corn, wheat, bread; lemons and misc. citrus on the nose; slightly off putting dirty feet edge too; soft, yeasty and wheaty on the palate; lemons, grain and wheat; quite tasty to be honest; drinks much better than it smells; my first zwickel/keller/landbier rating, whatever that means :)

In short: A pillowy nourishing, refreshing and hoppy golden lager.  Superior tasty session lager.
How: Can 473ml.  Consumed fresh a few weeks after receiving it from HogTownHarry.  Thanks a lot Harry.
The look: Partly cloudy golden orange topped by a medium white head
In long: Pleasant nose of hops that are between leafy and tea-like.  Reminds me of some Sterling based beer Ive had, I might be wrong though.  A smooth pillowy body with a nice marriage of the malts and yeast giving the beer a nice doughy and bready character.  Taste of citrusy dough, fresh white bread, floral notes, some grass, tree leaves, apricots.  Some unusual but not unpleasant vegetable notes (I did picked up carrot !?!).  Overall this beer feels nourishing and refreshing.  Very sessionnable.  In my country where we make shitty cars and female swimmer have less testosterones than I do, it is nice to find something that truly feels german.

500ml Can: I first tried this at the launch party at Victory Cafe, managed to find some cans in store tonight to try it again. Pours copper and cloudy, a very large foamy white head, excellent looking beer.  Aroma is sour lemon, brown sugar, fresh bread, hops.. wow, really nice. The first sip is bready, peach and a hop bite on the tip of the tongue, chased with a distinctive tea character.  Second sip I guzzled, grabbed some great hop bitterness with an almost Meyer lemon character, right back into that tea chaser. This is truly the lager for ale drinkers, tons of flavour and character, just an excellent job.
Amber colour with an aroma of hop and citrus.  Taste is superb.  Citrus playing on the palate with the hop bitterness on the way down.  A winner for Creemore, wish I bought more than one.

473 mL can. Pours a nice orangey-gold, with a frothy white head. Sharp hop aroma, with a hint of flowers and citrus. Very hoppy, though also very smooth and mild. Doesnt have the insane hop kick I was expecting, but the hops are certainly there and just counterbalanced by a smooth honey and citrus finish. Excellent balance found. Not an extreme beer, but has a great everyday beer quality to it.

473ml can acquired in trade with Sammy (thanks!). Poured a medium and cloudy golden color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of earthiness, floral hops, and citrus. Tastes of floral hops, lighter earthiness, some citrus, and graininess.
Pale amber-gold pour.  Nose is a bit sulphurous.  A touch of light breadiness as well.  Softly earthy and a little bit sweet.  A bit of DMS towards the finish.  Meh.

Can - 473ml. Superb hazy amber body with a generous white frothy head. Decent malty/hoppy aroma with some herbal and caramel hints. Its fresh hoppy taste carries citrusy and herbal notes. Ends with a good bitter finish. Good introduction to the style.

[2456-20090821] 473mL can. Fern plant hops aroma has hints of floral. Hazy, bright orange body with a long-lasting creamy white head. Grainy vegetal hops flavour has generic metallic qualities. Medium body. Not bad, interesting plant characteristics.
(from LCBO-Bayview, Toronto, ON)

Can. Wow, this beer has aromas of watermelon mostly, orange grapefruit and passion fruit too. Wonderfully fruity nose. The taste is more sweet fruit but with a hint of floral hops, good hop presence with a bit of spice too. Delicious.

473 mL can.  Looks like regular Creemore, only cloudy.  Great lacing, as with the original.  By the end of the glass, there was some grainy sediment in the bottom.  Grainy/earthy/herbal aroma.  Flavour has grainy malt, spiciness, a little thin caramel, and a slight bitterness.  Quite full and flavourful for a lager.  Another solid beer from Creemore.

Fizzy dark golden bordering on light orange. A small slice of white foam stays atop it all and does not last much despite the active bubbling. Grassy, softly earthy and lemony nose shows more hop character than anticipated. Leafy and fruity on the palate, its almost juicy in terms of flavours, yet bright and crisp in terms of carbonation. Not so yeasty, farmy, floral, pils malt focused like top German examples, but fresh and bright nonetheless, leaning more towards the tea-like/lemonade/peach nectar/apricot juice side of things, but refreshing and hugely drinkable. Id kinda stopped following Creemore Springs since a few years, but this is a most honourable new product. Lingering fruity, citrusy and herbal bitterness
Can. Nice beer. Pours a hazy dark orange colour with thin head. Aroma is grassy hops some citrus notes. Nice yeasty sediment. Taste has mild hops, finish has lingering hops.
can. Poured hazy amber with a thick off-white head. Sweet citric hop aroma. Full creamy mouthfeel, more citrus hoppy bitterness. Dry & spicy finish.

Thanks to the Queens RB crew! Pours a transparent orange with no head. Yeasty aroma with some mandarin oranges and grains. A bit pungent. Flavors of peach, lemon, wheat, and hops. The hoppy finish is a bit stale and flat. The peach was a nice surprise.

2009-07-31. Golden body with a foamy white head. Lightly yeasty aroma, bit floral, light zesty citrus. Flavour has a light bitternes, zippy floral hops, muted pale malt base. (6+) Average palate. Solid example of the style, quaffable, but not really my cup of tea. Can from LCBO

Can at BCTC 2009: Golden pour with a white film of head. Biscuity malt nose with some peppery noble hop character. Light body with a crisp dry flavor- biscuity and softly sweet malt character with a balancing noble hop presence. A very nice and German feeling lager.

Can @ BCTC courtesy of Jerc & Mabel. Light to medium amber pour. Floral, citrus, light bready aroma. Taste had caramel sweetness, floral grassy hops, light breadiness. Real tasty looking forward to having again

Can at BCTC.  Pours a light hazy apricot with a thin white head.  Citrus and caramel on the nose with some light malt.  Light malt on the body.  Finishes with a nice balancing bitterness.  Pretty solid.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2010 473mL can shared by matt7215 at our casual Saturday afternoon mini-tasting. Thanks Matt. Sampled side-by-side with Trois Mousquetaires Kellerbier. This one pours an only slightly hazy orange with a small white head. Wheres all my sediment? The aroma is definitely akin to everything I expect from Creemore. Corn, grain husks, sweet malts, but with a lot of citrus, tangerine, and a touch of dry hoppy yeastyness. Flavour is very smooth, mild carbonation which is good. Very sweet upfront, all the usual Creemore flavours but with some dry yeast and minor hop elements chiming in. Very simple actually, qutie drinkable though even as a fan of good lagers I dont completely comprehend the hype around this one. That said, Id still buy it semi-regularly if possible, and Im happy to see a more obscure style being produced in Ontario. Filter it even less and Id like it a lot more. EDIT: 2010 version is actually much better. Same elements but richer and better done. More noticable hop activity in the aroma and flavour, this tweaked version is one of the best things being done in this province IMHO.

Can from the LCBO. Appearance: Pinkish orange with a small off white head and good visible carbonation. Aroma:  Slight perfume, some grassy hops, malt, some light lemon peel and grain. Flavour: Initially malt, nice grassy hops (as opposed to the grassy hops that I personally dislike) a good creaminess to the body with a sweet hop finish, the more Im drinking it - the better its getting. Good work Creemore, a solid brew. Oh - refreshing too!

473 ml can from LCBO (last one!), served cold in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Hazy dirty amber with a large light tan froth.
  
Aroma:  Funky, earthy grassy, peppery hops, some light earthy malts, minerals, 
  
Palate:  Medium body and carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Lots of apricot/peach, biscuity malts to a lesser extent, some of the the Saaz hops, though not much, a little wet hay and a bit of black tea; dry with fair bitterness and a pleasant lightly-roasted malt finish. 

Beautiful.  I wonder how much influence Molson-Coors has on the wee town of Creemore...

473ml can, seasonal beer that caught my eye as I was leaving the LCBO

Pours a hazy golden colour with a decent light tan head. The aroma is very rich, malty and hoppy at once, a really nice blend of smells. The taste is very rich and flavorful. Very nice malt start which quickly turns into a more notable hops kick. They really have a nice hop blend in this beer and it translates nicely into the palate as well. A very full mouthfeel with the lingering hop bitterness.

Good work Creemore, keep em coming!

UPDATED: APR 28, 2012 473 ml can from the LCBO. pours a slightly hazed amber with a small white head. poor rentention but minimal carb. aroma of creemore house malt bill, slightly more hops then regular creemore (very fresh green hops), very fragrent but not totally exciting. the flavour is more polished then the aroma. natural progression from the malt to the hops and again the hops are very green and fresh. id filter it less (if possible) and hop it more. a nice beer though, great for the summer.

Pours a hazy orange colour with a thin white creamy head. The aroma is a little musty, insense, caramel, citus, floral hop. The flavour is strange, and interesting, has a hint of that mustiness in it, some caramel sweetness, vegetable broth, hops, ends on a mustiness. The mouthfeel is creamy.

This beer poured a dark orange colour with a nice big white head. To the nose there are scents of hopps, citrus, vegetables and pepper. First taste was smooth and very flavourful. Flavours of bitterness/hopps, vegetables and a little spice. Finish is hoppy with flavours of grass and a little caramel. Palate is lingering creamy (???) with hopp / bitterness receding.

50 cl can, Mulmur, ON, Canada, via the brewery. Slightly hazy copper colour, frothy head. Spicy aroma, slightly watery-er texture than I hoped for, although the mouthfeel was very nice with a smooth, velvety carbonation (if that is possible). Seems to be something in between the pilsner and their classic lager, a nice summer offering.

473 ml can - pours a hazy (but not as hazy as I was expecting) amber honey colour with a good sticky head.  For aroma, I get much of that familiar Creemore nose, but fuller and fresher - a bit of sulphur, light fruit, and a touch of hops.  Flavour is similar, with a yeasty, bready component.  A very nice beer, but Im not as blown away by it as others.  Similar to, but better than, the regular Creemore lager, and certainly better than the pilsner.  However, if you are not a fan of the Creemore house flavour, steer clear.

Can (473ml).  I hear great things about this one ...  Hazy amber, average white head (4-).  Solid aroma - light cereal/biscuity malt, a lot of floral/herbal bitterness - almost makes it to 8/10 but theres a little more alcohol on the nose than I would have expected, but thats a minor quibble.  Taste - very, very nice - fresh grassy/herbal bitterness and perfectly balancing biscuity malt - I get that little bit of lemon zest too - yummy.  Light, chewy, nice dry aftertaste - frankly, WAY better than what the normal Creemore has become over the past 5-6 years (I know, I know - "Molson hasnt changed anything!"  - bullshit).

Dark amber. Real hazy mabe opposed to cloudy. What I think of as European malt taste. Almost a hint of cinamon. A hint of lemon near the end. A noticeable but restrained hop presence. Solid lager with plenty of taste. Nice that it is in a 500ml can.

1st off I would like to thank molson for leaving creemore alone and letting them creat some outstanding lagers. Slightly hazy amber pour, beautiful nose of soft bscuitymalts and some really nice zesty slightly citrucy hops. Wow this beer is so smooth and soft I could exult drink this all day! Outstanding!

Can 473 ml served at cellar temperature 
Appearance:  neat shade of copper with hint of amber, slight haze, on top off tanned laced head.4+.Nose:  Superb softness. Silky aromatic slightly acidic alpha hop paired gently with sweet candy and pale malts. Complete meadow like fresh effect.8+ Flavor/Palate : Mid bodied with fuller walls. Fruity bitterness noted up front, hint of peach and hibiscus tea. Soft malting neatly rounds this creation up. Late leafy but not to dry hop accents shown. Quiet hoppy even for Keller. Best lager in Ontario by far.

Can- Deep hazy gold with orangey hues. A rocky and sticky cap sits atop the liquid, and leaves nice lace. Yeasty, citric nose that leads to fresh and pungent hops, bread crust, perfume. Flavours are fresh and bright. Lots of citrus, bready malts, fresh green hops, markedly spicy, with a floral/herbal quality. Medium bodied, with a subdued sweet fruity finish, and a pleasantly astringent bitterness that lingers. Complex, rewarding, and very drinkable. Excellent.

Can, LCBO 8 Pack.  Pours a very nice hazy golden yellow with an attractive creamy white head with great lacing.  A few streaming bubbles are present as well. Very inviting fresh aroma - bread, biscuit, wet trees in a forest (Im stretching, but that is what it smells like - so fresh). Taste - terrific.  Surprising hops right up front, giving way to fruity malt, and an interesting spicy hop finish.  Mouthfeel is very reminiscent of fresh Creemore lager, soft and actively carbonated.  That finish is something else - now Im getting honey and citrus to go with the spiciness.  Wow, there is a ton of flavour here, what a great job Creemore (and thanks for leaving them alone Molson)!  They knocked this one out of the park, not sure a lager could get any more flavourful.

Very natural and subtle Zwickel with prominent aromas of leafy wet hops. Ruddy gold with clear highlights and natural lacy foam. Taste is herbal-mineral and earthy over light sweetness countered by good hopping that is beautifully dry but not astringent. Light to medium feel, some lemon and fruit there too. Kinda got some attitude goin on.... 473 ml can from the LC boingo bobo - thanks!!

Can given to me by Troy Burtch. hazy orange color, lotsa lotsa foam. nose is bready with some good dry hopping. flavor was nice refreshing, malty with some good hops to balance it out. i am happy and surprised by this beer

473ml can, consumed 6 days after packaging.

Poured a hazy orange-gold lager in the stein, Frothy 2 finger cap with good retention and glass- lacing properties.

Pungent aroma of fresh bread and herbal-woody noble cones with a musty-earthy undertone.

Sturdy malt spine, ample body, creamy mouth feel, round mellow character and tons of flavor.

The front side of this beer assaults the senses with a big malt blast titrated by succulent herbal leafy hop balance, mid palate it mellows and the rounded aged character is evident, bready hoppy finish.

A faithful interpretation of this German lager style. Extremely fresh, flavorful and mellow. I wish all premium craft  lagers could satisfy this substantially with so much fresh flavor. I can see me going though my 4 cases rather fast.

Sad that your average lager quaffer is unaware of how much flavor is removed by filtering.

On tap @ Victory Cafes Release.

 Aroma is leafy wet hops, malty with some lovely fruit, unfiltered giving a cloudy orange marmalade colour, sporting a firm long lasting finger of custard head, some pretty lace too. The flavour is again fresh wet leafy hops, gorgeous malt, with apples and red pitfruit. Light bodied, especially well balanced, lucious mouthfeel, creamy smooth. The first two of three pints that I enjoyed, were not very cold, and came across like a cask version. I would suggest when this is available for purchase to try it just slightly cool. Terrific!

Creemore Springs release party at Victory Cafe.  Had this on tap, will be released in cans...just as now-unfiltered.  Peachy cloudy appearance with long lasting white generous head, leaving lace traces.  Yeasty and spicey and malty aroma. Medium mouthfeel, the yeast cushions but above average carbonation offsets this and prevents a full two pints from being consumed, still very drinkable.  Significant hops, including dry hopping, I like the unfiltered taste.  Drying finsh. Bang on style, it hits the ontario market between the eyes, and just as Creemore brought craft back in Ontario about 20 years back, this will be a paradigm shifter.
